Q: Implement ball bouncing in free fall using scipy.ivp() A:

I recently came across a similar issue in a simulation I was working on. Instead of trying to force the solution through solve_ivp I decided to figure out a way to implement this naturally through an ODE.

I envisioned what we are a bounce of a ball off a wall actually entails, it is a squashing and stretching, this effectively makes it a spring, and turns our problem into half of a simple harmonic oscillator ie. you treat this problem as one involving the dynamic of Hooke's Law (with a very high spring coefficient) when in contact with the wall (which is just whenever it exceeds a certain parameter), so that motion reverts. The only issue with this is that Hooke's Law is conservative and thus produces an elastic collision. I spent some time trying to figure out how to address this, and I believe the easiest is to split the ODE into two further cases, when "in contact" with the wall and heading into it use the standard (very high) spring constant, and when rebounding (moving away from the wall) multiply the spring constant by the desired coefficient of restitution of the collision (about 0.8 in your case I'd guess).

Example code below, I hope it's clear, this is my first time posting code directly here.

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from scipy.integrate import solve_ivp

# Plot Control
CentreZero = False

# Initial Position
ini_x = 0 #Metres
ini_y = 1 #Metres
ini_vx = 1 #Metres per second
ini_vy = 0 #Metres per second
ini = np.array([ini_x,ini_y,ini_vx,ini_vy])

# Constants
m = 10 #Kilograms
F_0 = 1500 #Newtons
a_g = -9.8 #Metres per second per second

# Initial Time
timestart = 0
timefin = 2

# Resolution
FinalResolution = 1000000

# Bounce
restit = 0.5 # Coefficient of Restitution
k = 100000000 # Spring Constant

def ODE(t, pos): # Wall bounce ODE
    vx = pos[2]
    vy = pos[3]
    if (pos[1] <= 0) and vy < 0:   
        ay = -k*pos[1]/m
    elif (pos[1] <= 0) and vy >= 0:   
        ay = -restit*k*pos[1]/m
    elif pos[1] >= 0:
        ay = a_g
    else:
        ay = 0
    ax = 0
    return np.array([vx,vy,ax,ay])

def frameexpand(data2, centrezero = False): # Function to make plotting more natural
    data = data2.copy()
    datatind = np.where(np.abs(data[0]) == np.inf)[0]
    dataxind = np.where(np.abs(data[1]) == np.inf)[0]
    dataind = np.concatenate((datatind, dataxind))
    datatloc = np.delete(data[0], dataind)
    dataxloc = np.delete(data[1], dataind)
    data = np.array([datatloc, dataxloc])
    minx = min(data[0]) - 0.1*abs(min(data[0]))
    maxx = max(data[0]) + 0.1*abs(max(data[0]))
    miny = min(data[1]) - 0.1*abs(min(data[1]))
    maxy = max(data[1]) + 0.1*abs(max(data[1]))
    if centrezero:
        xval = max(abs(minx), abs(maxx))
        yval = max(abs(miny), abs(maxy))
        return -xval, xval, -yval, yval
    return minx, maxx, miny, maxy

res = solve_ivp(ODE, (timestart, timefin), ini, t_eval = np.linspace(timestart, timefin, FinalResolution))

fig, ax = plt.subplots()

ax.plot(res.y[0], res.y[1])
ax.axis(frameexpand(res.y[0:2], CentreZero))
ax.grid(True, 'both')
ax.axhline(y=0, color='tab:green')
plt.xlabel('x position (m from origin)')
plt.ylabel('y position (m from origin)')
plt.savefig('Wall Bounce', dpi=1000)
plt.show();

This expresses that it seems to work as intended, and in most cases I've tested it works equally well (assuming high enough spring coefficient and solve_ivp resolution), but I'm not 100% sure and think I might have seen a case where it acts a little odd. I think it's an artifact of the interaction between the solver and when the steps in the ODE take place, though can't confirm for certain.

Q: Why are there double parentheses around my Python virtual environment in Visual Studio Code? A:

check the venv’s activation script:

nano venv/bin/activate

Look at this section of your activate script:

if [ -z "${VIRTUAL_ENV_DISABLE_PROMPT:-}" ] ; then
    _OLD_VIRTUAL_PS1="${PS1:-}"
    PS1="("'(venv) '") ${PS1:-}"
    export PS1
fi

Replace the problematic lines with:

if [ -z "${VIRTUAL_ENV_DISABLE_PROMPT:-}" ] ; then
    _OLD_VIRTUAL_PS1="${PS1:-}"
    PS1="(venv) ${PS1:-}"
    export PS1
fi
